PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Simply state facts of pioneer life if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

1. Your full name: ESTHER JEAN McCAMMON

2. Your address: PARADISE HILL, ALTA. MAY 1955

3. Date: JUNE 22, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): IRELAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation? FARMER, GREENHOLD

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MARCH 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   TRENTON, ONT. 1885-1890
   TORONTO, ONT. 1890-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I" in a statement)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   TO TEACH, (AS TEACHERS WERE FEW)
   AT $17.50 PER MONTH.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

THROUGH MY BROTHER, AMERICAN, IN NIPAWIN

AND MR. NELSON, BR.
1. Your full name: Esther Aeian McCammon

2. Your address: Paradise Hill, Prince Albert, Sask.

3. Date: July 22, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): County Tyrone, Ireland

5. What was your father's name and occupation? John McCammon, Farmer (Freehold)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March, 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   - Ages of 3, Trenton, Ont., 1885-1890
   - Ages of 4, Toronto, Ont., 1890-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you could not read or write at age 11 or 12, or if you were a small child). I was 11 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   To teach, (as teachers were few)

   $17.00 per month

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Through my brother, American in Moose Jaw

    Mr. Nelson, Br.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was too unsettled.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? CPR.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

MET OTHER TEACHERS. SAW AND MET

Educated people of Mennonite origin. Did working for us.

School officials. Met several government officials.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Moose Jaw (population 14,000) for 3 years.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

XX

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Tyrrell - 1 year

Dunvegan - 2 years

School closed through lack of pupils

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Did not

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

DRAWING THROUGH BLIZZARDS TO SHELTER,

SNOWED IN THE HOUSE, SOMETIMES FOR A WEEK,

COULD NOT GET VEGETABLES OR VEGETABLE PESTS OFTEN LIVED,

ON TURNIPS, OATMEAL AND COFFEE,

THE MAN OF THE HOUSE VISITED BACHELORS SHACKS,

FAMILIES TOOK CARE OF EACH OTHER,

SOMETIMES LOST ON PRAIRIE AND STAYED ALL NIGHT AT STRANGE SHACK WHERE I COULD GET SHELTER FOR MY HORSE.
